content: The "Inspector General Act Amendments of 2001" prohibits cash bonuses or awards for Inspector Generals and includes provisions for external reviews. The "Inspector General Act Amendments of 2001" require external reviews of Inspector General Offices every 3 years to evaluate their management of contracts. If a private entity is contracted for the review, it must comply with federal regulations. The Inspector General Act Amendments of 2001 mandate external reviews of Inspector General Offices every 3 years to assess contract management, fund usage, and personnel actions. Reports on the findings must be submitted within 30 days to the establishment head and relevant committees. Additionally, a technical amendment changes the section heading for section 4 of the Inspector General Act of 1978. The Inspector General Act Amendments of 2001 mandate annual reports summarizing activities and accomplishments, including high-risk program areas and significant audits, investigations, evaluations, and inspections completed during the reporting period. The annual report mandated by the Inspector General Act Amendments of 2001 includes summaries of activities, significant audits, investigations, evaluations, and inspections completed during the reporting period. It also includes reports made to the head of the establishment, a table showing final audit reports and associated financial benefits, and details on corrective actions and program improvements in response to audit findings or recommendations. The annual report includes a table showing judicial and administrative actions related to investigations by the Office of Inspector General, such as cases referred for prosecution, defendants indicted, and defendants convicted. The annual report includes information on defendants convicted, acquitted, sentenced to imprisonment or probation, and administrative actions taken. It also details fines, restitutions, and recoveries. Additionally, it describes the organization and management structure of the Office of Inspector General. The annual report includes details on authorized full-time positions, funding received, contracts awarded noncompetitively, contractor names, statement of work, contract duration, and dollar amounts. The annual report must include a summary of audit reports without management decisions, along with explanations for delays and desired timelines for decisions. Additionally, there are redesignations and amendments to specific paragraphs within the report. A report requested by the appropriate jurisdiction or the Comptroller General shall summarize the Office's activities during a 6-month period and be submitted by April 30 of the following year, unless the request is made after November 30. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to allow reports to be submitted after November 30 of the preceding year. This does not limit the Inspector General from submitting reports more frequently than annually or semiannually. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to reclassify various Inspector General positions from Level IV to Level III in different departments, including Education, Energy, Health and Human Services, Agriculture, Housing and Urban Development, Labor, Transportation, Veterans Affairs, and Defense. A savings provision ensures that the pay rate of current Inspector Generals will not be reduced. SEC. 6. STUDY AND REPORT ON CONSOLIDATION OF INSPECTOR GENERAL OFFICES. The Comptroller General of the United States will develop criteria for determining cost-efficient consolidation of Federal Inspector General offices and submit a report to Congress with recommendations for legislative action within 180 days.
